course_title: Special Topics: How We Reconstruct the Past

class_notes:
(Same as IDS 385W 1)
How, and using what evidence, do we reconstruct past events, beliefs, practices, and people? What is the history of how narratives and arguments about the past came to be? How are these narratives communicated to a broad audience? In this course, we will explore answers to these questions through case studies from ancient Egypt. We will discuss how scholars in various disciplines, including those from archaeology, history, art history, anthropology, philology, and biomedicine, have interpreted a variety of evidence to form narratives and arguments.
We will explore topics like the famous king Tutankhamun, and popular narratives of his death in a chariot crash, and ask questions of how we got this story of the famous king's death? Why is his cause of death interesting to different disciplines and audiences? What was the historical context that birthed such narratives and what continues to drive them today? By the end of this class, we will be able to critique the different approaches to reconstructing the past, evaluate narratives, and craft our own.
